summary: This is a transcript of a DOJ Office of the Inspector General interview with a New York City medical examiner who performed the autopsy on Jeffrey Epstein. The examiner details the autopsy findings, explains the medical evidence supporting a conclusion of suicide by hanging, and discusses questions about the ligature and the investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the autopsy and investigation. The medical examiner determined his cause of death was hanging and manner of death was suicide.

persons.name: Dr. Michael Baden
persons.context: Hired by Jeffrey Epstein's brother, Mark Epstein, to be present as an observer during the autopsy.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.context: Hired a private medical examiner, Dr. Michael Baden, to be present for Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy.

connections.description: Mark Epstein is the brother of Jeffrey Epstein and hired a private medical examiner for the autopsy.
Mark Epstein hired Dr. Michael Baden to observe the autopsy on his brother's behalf.
Dr. Baden was present as an independent observer during Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy, hired by the family.

events.title: Autopsy of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: The medical examiner conducted the autopsy of Jeffrey Epstein, finding evidence consistent with suicidal hanging.

events.title: Previous suicide attempt by Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found with a noose around his neck in an apparent previous suicide attempt while in custody.

events.title: DOJ OIG Interview
events.description: The DOJ Office of the Inspector General interviews the medical examiner who performed Epstein's autopsy as part of their investigation into his death.

locations: New York City Office of Chief Medical Examiner
Dane County Medical Examiner's Office, Madison, Wisconsin
keyFacts: The medical examiner found Jeffrey Epstein's death to be a 'very clear-cut' suicide by hanging based on autopsy findings including a ligature furrow, petechial hemorrhages, and specific fractures of the hyoid bone and thyroid cartilage.
The examiner noted confusion and lack of certainty about which piece of material presented was the actual ligature used, with at least two different cloth strips photographed at the scene.
No defensive wounds, signs of a struggle, or suspicious bruising were found on Epstein's body during the autopsy.
Toxicology tests detected no substances in Epstein's system at the time of death.

The medical examiner stated that no one attempted to coerce or bribe her into ruling the death a suicide, though she received unpleasant calls from Epstein's family who were unhappy with the determination.
